title: Sri Lanka to hike taxes back to 2019 levels: Minister
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka will hike taxes back to 2019 levels, under changes proposed by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe have been approved, cabinet spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said.
A supplementary estimate of 695 billion rupees will be presented to parliament.
Cabinet has approved changes to the following tax laws to raise revenue.
Sri Lanka cut taxes in December 2019 in a ‘fiscal stimulus, saying there was a ‘persistent output gap’ after two earlier currency crises in 2016 and 2018 reduced growth.
From February 2020, rates were cut and large volumes of money was printed to enforce the rates, driving the country into the worst currency crisis in the history of the soft-pegged central bank.
Currency crises are associated with soft pegs (intermediate regime central banks).

Sri Lanka is estimated to have lost about 600 billion rupees of the revenue year from the taxes, but 2.3 trillion have been printed over 24 months including to pay rejected bonds from previous deficits. (Colombo/May31/2022)
